commit_message:
Fix default bay create timeout

The default bay_create_timeout should be 0 if --timeout is ommitted.
We should not pass bay_create_timeout=None to magnum API.

Change-Id: Idabf62d1b71d887c0a0abb28f3a8c726da4ae9b5
Closes-Bug: #1522265

subject: Change $LOGFILE path in configuration devstack
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-15 17:20:11.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/dev/dev-manual-devstack.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/magnum/commit/906ce49cd44fd57386159e5a6d5cd6cbdca8a645', 'message': 'Change $LOGFILE path in configuration devstack

clean.sh in devstack removes $LOGFILE, $LOGDIR, $SCREEN_LOGDIR,
however $LOGDIR is set "$HOME"("${LOGFILE%/*}") now.
If you run clean.sh, $HOME will be deleted.
This patch avoids removing $HOME directory.

Change-Id: Ic1270134b40f581bb6ec3eb80d642e1e3fb5c5c3
Closes-bug: 1526433
'}]
commit_message:
Change $LOGFILE path in configuration devstack

clean.sh in devstack removes $LOGFILE, $LOGDIR, $SCREEN_LOGDIR,
however $LOGDIR is set "$HOME"("${LOGFILE%/*}") now.
If you run clean.sh, $HOME will be deleted.
This patch avoids removing $HOME directory.

Change-Id: Ic1270134b40f581bb6ec3eb80d642e1e3fb5c5c3
Closes-bug: 1526433
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/21/258021/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOGFILE=$HOME/logs/devstack.log

commit_message:
Follow up nits of Exception to str type conversion

This patch follows up nits of the commit [1], that is redundant str()
calls for Exception to str type conversion have been removed.

[1] I8c3b95ac3b83154c007e6f77582e2d0f93418a1d

Change-Id: I76464f2c16600977d837ee57f204d312fc7e06b9

commit_message:
Always log if disconnect from docker swarm

Currently, docker conductor conditionally log the exception. It could
cause lose of debug information.

Change-Id: I13d8a15e4731e5a4bae8d6cb80b054baf5a3dd42
Related-Bug: #1521395

deleted_lines: container_uuid = kwargs.get('container_uuid') if container_uuid is not None: LOG.exception(_LE("Error while connect to docker " "container %(name)s: %(error)s"), {'name': container_uuid, 'error': str(e)})

commit_message:
Manage keystone related configuration via Puppet

Keystone wise, the current state of this project is to initialize it and
manage it in a post-configure script.

Note: dropping computev3 resource with Puppet, because Puppet will
handle it with another name (novav3).
Change-Id: Iad619d3b10e8329234bdfb3fc738ed130e26fe3f

commit_message:
API: add filters when try to list containers

Add bay_ident as an optional parameter when try to list containers.

Partially implements: blueprint add-bay-column-to-container
Change-Id: Ie9461fb672abfc50f4648bae0999db2caf3939f6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/77/256477/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 1000, None, 'id', 'asc', filters=None) 1000, None, 'id', 'asc', filters=None) @patch('magnum.conductor.utils.retrieve_bay_uuid') @patch('magnum.objects.Container.list') def test_get_all_containers_with_bay_ident(self, mock_container_list, mock_retrive_bay_uuid, mock_container_show): test_container = utils.get_test_container() containers = [objects.Container(self.context, **test_container)] mock_container_list.return_value = containers mock_retrive_bay_uuid.return_value = '12' mock_container_show.return_value = containers[0] response = self.app.get('/v1/containers/?bay_ident=12') mock_container_list.assert_called_once_with(mock.ANY, 1000, None, 'id', 'asc', filters={'bay_uuid': '12'}) self.assertEqual(200, response.status_int) actual_containers = response.json['containers'] self.assertEqual(1, len(actual_containers)) self.assertEqual(test_container['uuid'], actual_containers[0].get('uuid')) @patch('magnum.conductor.api.API.container_show')

commit_message:
Make the db migration scripts complete

The current db migration scripts cannot reflect the db model we used.
This patch adds migration scripts for service related db and
some alterations on device and device attribute tables.

(cherry picked from commit 543c1edd60df5090a199dff9f7d637a2ae9c15a6)

Change-Id: I3a44c05280c4fa0b6bdb9737ec32200d641f2ac0
Closes-bug: 1518072

As described in the comments, CentOS overrides the "distroverpkg"
variable in yum.conf.  This is the package that yum queries to
establish the value of the $releasever variable.  On other platforms,
this defaults to "redhat-release" (which "fedora-release" provides) so
everything works.  It is only when the base-system "distroverpkg"
refers to a package not in the chroot we hit the issue.

We can avoid this by setting the releasever variable via the
commandline.

Change-Id: I231c3277960992cd479b8aff7838f246397936f2
'}]
commit_message:
Fix fedora-minimal on CentOS builds

As described in the comments, CentOS overrides the "distroverpkg"
variable in yum.conf.  This is the package that yum queries to
establish the value of the $releasever variable.  On other platforms,
this defaults to "redhat-release" (which "fedora-release" provides) so
everything works.  It is only when the base-system "distroverpkg"
refers to a package not in the chroot we hit the issue.

We can avoid this by setting the releasever variable via the
commandline.

Change-Id: I231c3277960992cd479b8aff7838f246397936f2

commit_message:
Sheepdog: Fix a problem about multi backend

Current Sheepdog driver does not support Cinder multi backend. It can
connect at most one Sheepdog cluster defined in the [DEFAULT] section
in the cinder.conf.

This patch makes Sheepdog driver support Cinder multi backend.
I think this should be treated as bug fix rather than enhancement
(i.e. adding a new feature) because Cinder itself has been supported
multi backend from Grizzly.

You can use multi Sheepdog clusters (for example, one of them has
low-performance SATA disk and another has high-performance SSD) with
cinder.conf like as below:

  [DEFAULT]
  enabled_backends=sheep0,sheep1
  [sheep0]
  volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.sheepdog.SheepdogDriver
  sheepdog_store_address=127.0.0.1
  sheepdog_store_port=7000
  volume_backend_name=sheep_SATA
  [sheep1]
  volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.sheepdog.SheepdogDriver
  sheepdog_store_address=127.0.0.1
  sheepdog_store_port=7001
  volume_backend_name=sheep_SSD

DocImpact

Closes-Bug: #1514353

Change-Id: I484430e52aa0661bf1cddf9939ad308e274317e2

commit_message:
Use Ansible AIO playbook for run-aio-build.sh

The new Ansible AIO playbook requires Ansible to be installed *prior*
to running the AIO bootstrap script.

Implements: blueprint convert-aio-bootstrap-to-ansible

Change-Id: I28af8a587bde629fd0c81a6c4ba47dd64c2e44db
(cherry picked from commit 55193774fcbf94fc7f276ea82998e79dcf95b127)

commit_message:
Add neutron_ceilometer_enabled default

This patch adds a default for neutron_ceilometer_enabled as it is
missing from the defaults and causing playbook execution failures
when this variable is not set.

Change-Id: I00b432e3e0c6698bc47a05eeaaccddbcc378bfd5
(cherry picked from commit b5a9eb519966bbf387d7fb82b699a85682b8980c)

commit_message:
rbac: add some backport compat tests

The old rbac wasn't really works only the segregration was applied.
Even it's fixed now the legacy policy.json should continue to works.

Change-Id: I050b2245d78780cb49b47b317a1a245b8e0a58eb

commit_message:
Test 'string' behaviour of get_object

Add a unit test to test the 'string' like behaviour of
get_object when it is called without resp_chunk_size set.

Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I496032a76036141d027c30b076c810b34bc6bef0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/18/258018/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_get_object_as_string(self): c.http_connection = self.fake_http_connection(200, body='abcde') __, resp = c.get_object('http://storage.example.com', 'TOKEN', 'container_name', 'object_name') self.assertEqual(resp, 'abcde')

commit_message:
remove py26 specific code from heatclient

test_shell had helper functions when testing with py26, but in the
mitaka release, py26 support was dropped from all projects, so
remove some of the py26 specific code in heatclient.

Change-Id: I511e2db3ddc703a65e457db647a2f8e898d3ac3d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/56/257156/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-15 20:04:36.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/e95a8b9ae90056ae5d742b016f8107383dec4b84', 'message': "Add bashate tox command

(bashate) that will check the syntax of the shell scripts under

The scripts under devstack/tools/ are not being checked, that's because

commit_message:
Add bashate tox command

Now that we copied the devstack code to our tree we need to ensure that
the bash scripts we have are correct. This patch is adding a tox command
(bashate) that will check the syntax of the shell scripts under
the devstack/ directory.

The scripts under devstack/tools/ are not being checked, that's because
they weren't check when the code was in devstack as well and there's
loads to fix. It will be fixed in a following patch.

Change-Id: I8f66492081e0fd10e1de057febb9324a81411c7a
Partial-Bug: #1526518
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/28/258128/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py34,py27,pep8,bashate[testenv:bashate] deps = {env:BASHATE_INSTALL_PATH:bashate==0.3.2} whitelist_externals = bash # TODO(lucasagomes): Check the tools/ directory as well commands = bash -c "find {toxinidir}/devstack \ -not \( -type d -name .?\* -prune \) \ # prune all 'dot' dirs -type f \ # only files -not -name \*.swp \ # skip editor files -not -name \*~ \ # skip editor files -not -name \*.xml \ # skip xml files -not -name \*.template \ # skip template files \( \ -name \*.sh -or \ # add files eding with .sh -wholename \*/lib/\* \ # add files under lib/ \) \ -print0 | xargs -0 bashate -v -iE006 -eE005,E042"

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-14 06:13:15.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/35ed0dd1fa2345a32c02a82026c16190086dd0de', 'message': "Volume migration: add 'name_id' as valid skippable field

New Versioned Objects expect 'name_id' as a valid input, which
is able to change '_name_id' as well, so this patch adds
'name_id' into the fields, which are going to skip for the
creation of the target volume during migration.

Change-Id: I91e3bc05607243aef020f461a467e9ecb956544f
Closes-Bug: #1525781
"}]
commit_message:
Volume migration: add 'name_id' as valid skippable field

New Versioned Objects expect 'name_id' as a valid input, which
is able to change '_name_id' as well, so this patch adds
'name_id' into the fields, which are going to skip for the
creation of the target volume during migration.

Change-Id: I91e3bc05607243aef020f461a467e9ecb956544f
Closes-Bug: #1525781
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/40/257140/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: skip = {'id', '_name_id', 'name_id', 'name', 'host', 'status',

commit_message:
Drop py33 support

"Python 3.3 support is being dropped since OpenStack Liberty."
written in following URL.
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3

And already the infra team and the oslo team are dropping py33
support from their projects.

Since we rely on oslo for a lot of our work, and depend on infra
for our CI, we should drop py33 support too.

Change-Id: I34bbced8f72cad0146a0f2bc964b1e093fbf7255
Closes-Bug: #1526170
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-manilaclient refs/changes/50/257750/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Adding administrative tasks for flask

Add a file manage.py where all administrative tasks related to the flask
app should be located, for now just a single task is being provided
which lists all the available routes

Change-Id: I66687a4fa673574fce9c90aae4fbdcdd7370cbab
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health refs/changes/68/230168/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from flask.ext.script import Manager from flask import url_for from api import app manager = Manager(app) @manager.command def list_routes(): import urllib output = [] for rule in app.url_map.iter_rules(): options = {} for arg in rule.arguments: options[arg] = "[{0}]".format(arg) methods = ','.join(rule.methods) url = url_for(rule.endpoint, **options) line = urllib.unquote("{:50s} {:20s} {}".format(rule.endpoint, methods, url)) output.append(line) for line in sorted(output): print(line) if __name__ == "__main__": manager.run()

commit_message:
Improve examples for how to use networking-sfc Devstack plugin

The original example was a bit odd and probably not what users
would typically want to use. This gives two examples with explanation
for where each is appropriate.

Change-Id: Idd256e5d632476713614b7e8d9bfcb40bcf76179
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-sfc refs/changes/90/258090/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: If you have already cloned the networking-sfc repository (which is useful when testing unmerged changes) enable_plugin networking-sfc /opt/stack/networking-sfc Or, if you want to pull the networking-sfc repository from Github and use a particular branch (for example Liberty, here) enable_plugin networking-sfc git://git.openstack.org/openstack/networking-sfc stable/liberty

commit_message:
Add run_stress to cliff-based cli framework

Also disable ability to run script in stand-alone mode. So users need to
use 'tempest run-stress' instead.

Change-Id: I3effd1b71b2375f75a11f5924205741be0903361
Implements: blueprint tempest-cli-improvements

added_lines: from cliff import command class TempestRunStress(command.Command): def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(TempestRunStress, self).get_parser(prog_name) parser.add_argument('-d', '--duration', default=300, type=int, help="Duration of test in secs") parser.add_argument('-s', '--serial', action='store_true', help="Trigger running tests serially") parser.add_argument('-S', '--stop', action='store_true', default=False, help="Stop on first error") parser.add_argument('-n', '--number', type=int, help="How often an action is executed for each process") group = parser.add_mutually_exclusive_group(required=True) group.add_argument('-a', '--all', action='store_true', help="Execute all stress tests") parser.add_argument('-T', '--type', help="Filters tests of a certain type (e.g. gate)") parser.add_argument('-i', '--call-inherited', action='store_true', default=False, help="Call also inherited function with stress attribute") group.add_argument('-t', "--tests", nargs='?', help="Name of the file with test description") return parser def take_action(self, pa): result = 0 if not pa.all: tests = json.load(open(pa.tests, 'r')) else: tests = discover_stress_tests(filter_attr=pa.type, call_inherited=pa.call_inherited) if pa.serial: # Duration is total time duration = pa.duration / len(tests) for test in tests: step_result = driver.stress_openstack([test], duration, pa.number, pa.stop) # NOTE(mkoderer): we just save the last result code if (step_result != 0): result = step_result if pa.stop: return result else: result = driver.stress_openstack(tests, pa.duration, pa.number, pa.stop) return result
deleted_lines: parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description='Run stress tests') parser.add_argument('-d', '--duration', default=300, type=int, help="Duration of test in secs") parser.add_argument('-s', '--serial', action='store_true', help="Trigger running tests serially") parser.add_argument('-S', '--stop', action='store_true', default=False, help="Stop on first error") parser.add_argument('-n', '--number', type=int, help="How often an action is executed for each process") group = parser.add_mutually_exclusive_group(required=True) group.add_argument('-a', '--all', action='store_true', help="Execute all stress tests") parser.add_argument('-T', '--type', help="Filters tests of a certain type (e.g. gate)") parser.add_argument('-i', '--call-inherited', action='store_true', default=False, help="Call also inherited function with stress attribute") group.add_argument('-t', "--tests", nargs='?', help="Name of the file with test description") def main(): ns = parser.parse_args() result = 0 if not ns.all: tests = json.load(open(ns.tests, 'r')) else: tests = discover_stress_tests(filter_attr=ns.type, call_inherited=ns.call_inherited) if ns.serial: # Duration is total time duration = ns.duration / len(tests) for test in tests: step_result = driver.stress_openstack([test], duration, ns.number, ns.stop) # NOTE(mkoderer): we just save the last result code if (step_result != 0): result = step_result if ns.stop: return result else: result = driver.stress_openstack(tests, ns.duration, ns.number, ns.stop) return result if __name__ == "__main__": try: sys.exit(main()) except Exception: LOG.exception("Failure in the stress test framework") sys.exit(1)

commit_message:
Skip test_baremetal_server_ops

Now gate-tempest-ironic-agent_ssh job fails many times, and it is
blocking tempest development also.
We have enough logs for the investigation already, then this patch
makes the test skipped.

Change-Id: Ie8e8a143014976046d3f55de8deafb998cdc6b3d
Related-Bug: #1393009

commit_message:
when fetching object store properties use lower()

sometimes properties within object store concepts are stored with
mixed case depending on the client used to store said properties.

when retrieving properties to 'show' the user, always call lower()
on the property in question when comparing it to the reserved
values of the swift API.

Change-Id: I97ffc715788ca3cd021413124b6945a399465c99
Closes-Bug: 1525805

commit_message:
Update SAIO setup for Ubuntu 14.04

Latest version of SAIO setup from source is failing on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS
machines. This patch adds the steps to address those.

Change-Id: Id41fbd49f5c34071bb5ce02c0ace3034c4ea63dd
Signed-off-by: Ganesh Maharaj Mahalingam <ganesh.mahalingam@intel.com>

added_lines: python-mock libpython3.4-dev If you are doing this install of a Ubuntu 14.04 LTS installation, there is a good chance you will run into one of the below errors .. code-block:: shell swift@swift-test-ubuntu:~/swift$ sudo python setup.py develop error in setup command: Invalid environment marker: (python_version>='3.0') .. code-block:: shell swift@swift-test-ubuntu:~$ cd $HOME/swift; sudo pip install -r requirements.txt; sudo python setup.py develop; cd - Exception: Traceback (most recent call last): File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/basecommand.py", line 122, in main status = self.run(options, args) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/commands/install.py", line 262, in run for req in parse_requirements(filename, finder=finder, options=options, session=session): File "/usr/lib/pyt hon2.7/dist-packages/pip/req.py", line 1632, in parse_requirements req = InstallRequirement.from_line(line, comes_from, prereleases=getattr(options, "pre", None)) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/req.py", line 173, in from_line return cls(req, comes_from, url=url, prereleases=prereleases) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/req.py", line 71, in __init__ req = pkg_resources.Requirement.parse(req) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources.py", line 2667, in parse reqs = list(parse_requirements(s)) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources.py", line 2605, in parse_requirements line, p, specs = scan_list(VERSION,LINE_END,line,p,(1,2),"version spec") File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources.py", line 2583, in scan_list "Expected ',' or end-of-list in",line,"at",line[p:] ValueError: ("Expected ',' or end-of-list in", "dnspython>=1.12.0;python_version<'3.0'", 'at', ";python_version<'3.0'") The default pip package distributed with the OS is version 1.5.4 while the current setup requires the latest (7.1.2). The below steps will fix the issues. .. code-block:: shell sudo apt-get remove python-pip wget https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py sudo python get-pip.py sudo pip install -U pip tox pbr virtualenv setuptools

commit_message:
Increasing max AIO kernel limit

When using multipath, the stock AIO limit per process is
to low and needs to be increased to at least 128k
This fix will increase the fs.aio-max-nr to 128k

Change-Id: Id6d8d2cb103483f75ba7b9c7b1022ebca4f143ea
Related-Bug: #1524957

commit_message:
Merge bashate/pep8 lint jobs in common job

Instead of launching two separate build jobs in our CI infrastructure,
one for bashate and one for pep8, launch a single one. While the jobs
are short, the setup of the images takes a long time, so this is
friendlier to our CI infrastructure.

Use the pep8 environment as common lint target and merge the bashate job
into it.

This patch also renamed dev-requirements to test-requirements to bring it
into line with all other OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: I1bf8c9b604d753237c0c007b5bc81586b4437283

commit_message:
Updating AIO docs for Ansible playbook

This documentation update ensures that deployers can still perform an AIO
playbook with the new Ansible-based AIO playbook. More docs will come
soon to provide additional explanation for the bootstrap options within
the playbook.

Implements: blueprint convert-aio-bootstrap-to-ansible

Change-Id: I730c838a67ca03413fbdfa43ef7606d8cf2f9cd0
(cherry picked from commit 3ebad4d2c355d346018fa0af988dca5ccc540607)

Restore sanity_check tests

These tests were incorrectly skipped in stable/liberty as part of
I42c1f67f223173c78b0ff1c501bed017855873e0 fix. They do not fail on
stable/liberty and should be restored

Change-Id: Id1382e4ea15dc04d9426e8adb284f6ec26ec6469

Updated Cloudsample

Uses configuration options to determine if a token is for the admin
project and should be granted admin privileges.

Closes-Bug: 968696

Change-Id: Ib23452e171dc90115c77fa5a4b9dc4649054eb0e

commit_message:
Keystone slaveification

Starting from Juno we've got an slave_connection to MySQL. In order to
increase API performance various operations can be send to slave.

Change-Id: If84045edccf16a81f37e8ec81400748a14dcbb52
Implements: blueprint keystone-slaveification
Depends-On: I80ba9d62f669e56e3d188fbc59ac1f8be716406c
Signed-off-by: Vladimir Eremin <yottatsa@yandex-team.ru>

deleted_lines: with sql.transaction() as session: with sql.transaction() as session:

commit_message:
Cleanup lock files for volume/snap after deletion

Currently, the lock files for volumes/snapshot will never get cleaned
up leaving many stray lock files The problem can't easily be solved
in the locking library because it's not trivial to tell when no
processes are waiting for a lock. Instead, this change
periodically checks which volumes and snapshots have been deleted
and removes any locks for that belonged to the resource.

Change-Id: I53ca7962f051aa5154cd32e45a5f3b187eb7dbb2
Closes-Bug: #1432387

added_lines: def fake_get_volume_lock_path(vol_id): return "%s/%s" % (CONF.volumes_dir, vol_id) def is_lock_old_enough_to_cleanup(*args): return True def get_expected_lock_calls(res_action, locked_res_id_list): expected_call_list = [] for res_id in locked_res_id_list: for lock_action in ['lock', 'unlock']: expected_call_list.append("%s/%s-%s" % (fake_get_volume_lock_path(res_id), lock_action, res_action)) return expected_call_list self.stubs.Set(vol_manager, 'get_volume_lock_path', fake_get_volume_lock_path) def _mock_synchronized(self, name, external, lock_path): self.called.append('%s/lock-%s' % (lock_path, name)) self.called.append('%s/unlock-%s' % (lock_path, name)) snap_locks = get_expected_lock_calls("delete_snapshot", [snap_id]) dst_vol_locks = get_expected_lock_calls("delete_volume", [dst_vol_id]) src_vol_locks = get_expected_lock_calls("delete_volume", [src_vol_id]) # Call order is snapshot locked while vol created from it, dest volume # deleted, snap deleted, src vol deleted expected_calls = (snap_locks + dst_vol_locks + snap_locks + src_vol_locks) self.assertEqual(expected_calls, id_list = [src_vol_id, dst_vol_id, src_vol_id] self.assertEqual(get_expected_lock_calls('delete_volume', id_list), def test_volume_locks_cleaned_up(self): self.stubs.Set(self.volume, 'is_lock_old_enough_to_cleanup', is_lock_old_enough_to_cleanup) volume = tests_utils.create_volume(self.context, **self.volume_params) volume_id = volume['id'] self.volume.create_volume(self.context, volume_id) instance_uuid = '12345678-1234-5678-1234-567812345678' mountpoint = '/dev/vdb' attachment = self.volume.attach_volume(self.context, volume_id, instance_uuid, None, mountpoint, 'ro') self.volume.detach_volume(self.context, volume_id, attachment['id']) vol_lock_path = fake_get_volume_lock_path(volume_id) self.assertTrue(os.path.isdir(vol_lock_path)) self.volume.delete_volume(self.context, volume_id) self.volume.cleanup_locks(None) self.assertFalse(os.path.isdir(vol_lock_path))
deleted_lines: def _mock_synchronized(self, name, *s_args, **s_kwargs): self.called.append('lock-%s' % (name)) self.called.append('unlock-%s' % (name)) self.assertEqual(['lock-%s' % ('%s-delete_snapshot' % (snap_id)), 'unlock-%s' % ('%s-delete_snapshot' % (snap_id)), 'lock-%s' % ('%s-delete_volume' % (dst_vol_id)), 'unlock-%s' % ('%s-delete_volume' % (dst_vol_id)), 'lock-%s' % ('%s-delete_snapshot' % (snap_id)), 'unlock-%s' % ('%s-delete_snapshot' % (snap_id)), 'lock-%s' % ('%s-delete_volume' % (src_vol_id)), 'unlock-%s' % ('%s-delete_volume' % (src_vol_id))], self.assertEqual(['lock-%s' % ('%s-delete_volume' % (src_vol_id)), 'unlock-%s' % ('%s-delete_volume' % (src_vol_id)), 'lock-%s' % ('%s-delete_volume' % (dst_vol_id)), 'unlock-%s' % ('%s-delete_volume' % (dst_vol_id)), 'lock-%s' % ('%s-delete_volume' % (src_vol_id)), 'unlock-%s' % ('%s-delete_volume' % (src_vol_id))],

commit_message:
Setup for translation

To start translation, we need to initially import the translation
file - and place it at the proper place so that the usual CI
scripts can handle it. The proper place is for all python
projects $PROJECT/locale/$PROJECT.pot - see setup.cfg.

Further imports will be done by the OpenStack Proposal bot.

Change-Id: Ic405c8a808ee4eae0393e6f08da8f1569b326a59

commit_message:
Setup for translation

To start translation, we need to initially import the translation
file - and place it at the proper place so that the usual CI
scripts can handle it. The proper place is for all python
projects $PROJECT/locale/$PROJECT.pot - see setup.cfg.

Further imports will be done by the OpenStack Proposal bot.

Change-Id: Ica2b1f8adc611af5cfa2cef715526d2764c62427

commit_message:
Fix incorrect metadata_dir for murano::dashboard

According to murano-dashboard package murano::dashboard points
to incorrect metadata_dir by default.

Downstream fix is merged, so we need to update tag for puppet-murano.
Downstream Fix: https://review.fuel-infra.org/#/c/14670/

commit_message:
Add OSSN-0062

This adds an OSN about a token revocation bypass issue that affects
the PKI/PKIZ keystone token providers.

Change-Id: I532ab4d06a58f154a87ddd9ba2fc1160912a7d6e
Related-bug: #1490804
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/19/258119/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Potential reuse of revoked Identity tokens --- ### Summary ### An authorization token issued by the Identity service can be revoked, which is designed to immediately make that token invalid for future use. When the PKI or PKIZ token providers are used, it is possible for an attacker to manipulate the token contents of a revoked token such that the token will still be considered to be valid. This can allow unauthorized access to cloud resources if a revoked token is intercepted by an attacker. ### Affected Services / Software ### Keystone, Icehouse, Juno, Kilo, Liberty ### Discussion ### Token revocation is used in OpenStack to invalidate a token for further use. This token revocation takes place automatically in certain situations, such as when a user logs out of the Dashboard. If a revoked token is obtained by another party, it should no longer be possible to use it to perform any actions within the cloud. Unfortunately, this is not the case when the PKI or PKIZ token providers are used. When a PKI or PKIZ token is validated, the Identity service checks it by searching for a revocation by the entire token. It is possible for an attacker to manipulate portions of an intercepted PKI or PKIZ token that are not cryptographically protected, which will cause the revocation check to improperly consider the token to be valid. ### Recommended Actions ### We recommend that you do not use the PKI or PKIZ token providers. The PKI and PKIZ token providers do not offer any significant benefit over other token providers such as the UUID or Fernet. If you are using the PKI or PKIZ token providers, it is recommended that you switch to using another supported token provider such as the UUID provider. This issue might be fixed in a future update of the PKI and PKIZ token providers in the Identity service. To check what token provider you are using, you must look in the 'keystone.conf' file for your Identity service. An example is provided below: ---- begin keystone.conf sample snippet ---- [token] #provider = keystone.token.providers.pki.Provider #provider = keystone.token.providers.pkiz.Provider provider = keystone.token.providers.uuid.Provider ---- end keystone.conf sample snippet ---- In the Liberty release of the Identity service, the token provider configuration is different than previous OpenStack releases. An example from the Libery release is provided below: ---- begin keystone.conf sample snippet ---- [token] #provider = pki #provider = pkiz provider = uuid ---- end keystone.conf sample snippet ---- These configuration snippets are using the UUID token provider. If you are using any of the commented out settings from these examples, your cloud is vulnerable to this issue and you should switch to a different token provider. ### Contacts / References ### This OSSN : https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OSSN/OSSN-0061 Original LaunchPad Bug : https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1490804 OpenStack Security ML : openstack-security@lists.openstack.org OpenStack Security Group : https://launchpad.net/~openstack-ossg CVE: CVE-2015-7546

commit_message:
Do not create duplicate dnsmasq_dhcp_ranges

After implementing the possibility to share L2/L3 parameters
between networks it became possible to have duplicate DHCP ranges.
So we need to check for already created resources in
create_dnsmasq_dhcp_ranges function to not create duplicates.

Change-Id: I5a48a8130bb63a77551ef06cb3bdf67c1bf203aa
Closes-bug: #1526360

commit_message:
Bump Glance ref on a new tag

Update Glance ref on a new tag, because was merged upstream change [1],
which closes bug (#1499754).

Currently during deployment Glance (with Swift as backend) we have
reference to every glance image in database with credentials, like:
swift+http://services%glance:EF3tluYM@192.168.0.2:5000/v2.0/glance/049cd701

This is not correct, because if someone will change glance credentials in conf
file, this reference will be invalid.

[1] Iaf0c1c6f2188c84267e41d2d4f9bda0dbf3dccad

Closes-bug: #1499754

Change-Id: I7e80f43a8e7664eeb469a7627022c37498be712c

commit_message:
limits supports a tenant_id parameter

Adds the optional query parameter of tenant_id that is supported by the
limits API.

This detail was found by comparing the v2.0-ext doc with the v2.1 doc.

Change-Id: Ic67e95e67ed3f89f8446fd01bff9eecc5994844b

commit_message:
Document using a pending review

Uses the shiny new source admonition to document how to use a
pending review from a puppet module.  This can be useful when
testing changes that depend on in-progress puppet changes.

Change-Id: Iceaa6df4766d51c66b1b3f1293f43c038efb3517
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/70/226570/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. admonition:: Source :class: source To use a git checkout for only a specific module, export the following variable:: export DIB_INSTALLTYPE_puppet_tripleo=source Replace ``puppet_tripleo`` with the name of the puppet module to be installed from source, replacing any -'s with _'s. To use a pending review for a module, set its installtype to source as described above, then also export the following variables:: export DIB_REPOLOCATION_puppet_tripleo=https://review.openstack.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo export DIB_REPOREF_puppet_tripleo=refs/changes/30/223330/1 This time replace the name of the module in the variable name and the review URL. The correct value for the ``reporef`` can be found in the ``Download`` section of the Gerrit UI. Look for a string that matches the format of the example above.

commit_message:
Object: Add filters to contianer list

This patch addes filters when doing container.list().
One example is when list containter, we might want only list some specify
contianers with given bay_uuid:
objects.Container.list(context, filters={'bay_uuid': 'uuid'})

Partially implements: blueprint add-bay-column-to-container
Change-Id: Ia2f7e6664b8dce77c61bdf18c1ffecd28c8c49b8

commit_message:
Update telemetry API v2 to make these changes

- Spell-check and remove passive voice
- Renamed code samples using this naming convention:
  <resource>-<action>-request.json or <resource>-<action>-response.json.
  For example, volume-create-request.json and volume-create-response.json.
- Removed unused code samples
- Made method names consistent throughout - use list<resource> for list
  operations, show<resource> for show operations, and so on.

Change-Id: I1fa3f4c2170f6472ea54575d16b62187b0ac0bb3
Partial-Bug: #1521244

commit_message:
Remove clients from default PROJECTS list

Devstack by default installs client libs from pypi and not from source
so we don't need to set them all up by default here. Also due to
implementation details of how the ironic jobs work we remove ironic as
well. The cross project dep ensures the jobs are all explicitly setting
this up as necessary before removing it from d-g.

Change-Id: Iabf4c0c22413b0d238f3b40822fb7c2ed84c2e0e

commit_message:
Make v3 update_user_password use **kwargs

As we discussed on
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-July/068864.html
All http POST/PUT methods need to contain **kwargs as their arguments.

This patch makes update_user_password of v3 identity_client use **kwargs.
Also update doc string for the same.

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: I6507e87a02f94191f5bfd6c9c1c1b18a88f4c532

commit_message:
Provide option to only validate template

The heat-translator users may only want to validate template without an actual
translation. Create a new optional arg that will only validate template
without running translation.

Change-Id: Ibd17042b365c4c24940e693b87f908a38c681391
Partially Implements: blueprint template-validation-only
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-translator refs/changes/80/257380/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Test the heat-translator translation from command line as:In order to use heat-translator to only validate template, without actual translation, pass --validate-only=true along with other required arguments. validate_only = None if len(args) > 2: parameters = None for arg in args: if "--validate-only=" in arg: validate_only = arg if "--parameters=" in arg: parameters = arg if parameters: parsed_params = self._parse_parameters(parameters) run_only_validation = False if validate_only: value = validate_only.split('-validate-only=')[1].lower() if template_type == 'tosca' and value == 'true': run_only_validation = True if run_only_validation: ToscaTemplate(path, parsed_params, a_file) else: heat_tpl = self._translate(template_type, path, parsed_params, a_file) if heat_tpl: self._write_output(heat_tpl)
deleted_lines: Test the heat-translator from command line as:This is an entry point for testing purpose on CLI. if len(args) > 2: parsed_params = self._parse_parameters(args[2]) heat_tpl = self._translate(template_type, path, parsed_params, a_file) if heat_tpl: self._write_output(heat_tpl)

Enable and fix pez unit tests

were not updated in a while. This enables them and fixes them up.

commit_message:
Fix router debug command

After the changes for drivers in Liberty, the astara-debug-router script
was broken.  This script helps to debug how a worker processes a single
message and enables PDB usage.

This is a modified backport since the files were moved in the master branch.

Change-Id: I69f04ff6f04a58d45737dca770f585f468e3ad58

commit_message:
Merge bashate/pep8 lint jobs in common job

Instead of launching two separate build jobs in our CI infrastructure,
one for bashate and one for pep8, launch a single one. While the jobs
are short, the setup of the images takes a long time, so this is
friendlier to our CI infrastructure.

Use the pep8 environment as common lint target and merge the bashate job
into it.

This patch also renamed dev-requirements to test-requirements to bring it
into line with all other OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: Ieeffb7719b88213aaafa02073f931c491d3deee3

commit_message:
Rename key_management to key_manager

Some time ago, the Key Management service was renamed to Key Manager
service in the governance repo. We originally stuck to naming it Key
Management *because* it was named as such in the projects.yaml file, and
because it has changed, we should follow how it's named there.

Change-Id: Id5c1bd617a02e21e91f01ec095f817222c535138

commit_message:
Add neutron/plugin/common/constants.py module to neutron-lib

This patch proposes the addition of plugin constants module to
neutron-lib. Instead of creating a new file plugin_constants,
this patch appends them to the existing constants module
within neutron-lib.

Change-Id: Id1cb3b36a0409660ff585ef098f5315ccd37af9f
Implements: blueprint neutron-lib

commit_message:
Fixed k8s redis example in quickstart guide

The demo of redis replication controller didn't work for a while.
The reason is that the redis-sentinel failed right after it starts.
That is because the docker image is incorrectly built.

As part of the fix, a fixed redis image was built and uploaded to
docker hub. We temporarily switch to the fixed image until the
official image is fixed.

Closes-Bug: #1523040
Change-Id: I19ca2f1c6df13b9592af7434fa3a7df49dfc79b3

Make tacker-db-manage revision 'xxx' --autogenerate work

We have to make db model visible to tacker-db-manage for it
to work well.

commit_message:
Block requests 2.9.0

The 2.9.0 release updates to urllib3 1.13 which has a regression
related to parsing IPv6 hostnames in URLs. This breaks nova and
oslo.service unit testing (at least).

This will be fixed in requests 2.10.0.

Upstream issue:

https://github.com/shazow/urllib3/issues/760

Change-Id: Ifb080c72a16ed4b93040fb7c06bdc072b7247f6e
Related-Bug: #1526413

commit_message:
Merge bashate/pep8 lint jobs in common job

Instead of launching two separate build jobs in our CI infrastructure,
one for bashate and one for pep8, launch a single one. While the jobs
are short, the setup of the images takes a long time, so this is
friendlier to our CI infrastructure.

Use the pep8 environment as common lint target and merge the bashate job
into it.

This patch also renamed dev-requirements to test-requirements to bring it
into line with all other OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: I19c4d9577ff86325fc87b9c03825f40defeeb273

commit_message:
Drop py33 support

"Python 3.3 support is being dropped since OpenStack Liberty."
written in following URL.
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3

And already the infra team and the oslo team are dropping py33
support from their projects.

Since we rely on oslo for a lot of our work, and depend on infra
for our CI, we should drop py33 support too.

Change-Id: Ic9d4f64154a5418baa159a4efdcd9dd652d142ff
Closes-Bug: #1526170

commit_message:
Merge bashate/pep8 lint jobs in common job

Instead of launching two separate build jobs in our CI infrastructure,
one for bashate and one for pep8, launch a single one. While the jobs
are short, the setup of the images takes a long time, so this is
friendlier to our CI infrastructure.

Use the pep8 environment as common lint target and merge the bashate job
into it.

This patch also renamed dev-requirements to test-requirements to bring it
into line with all other OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: I128cdf0bc0efdfc0fc4b4f0e1f40899a62f8b560

commit_message:
Remove unused filter on ansible-..-bashate

The bashate jobs have been made part of pep8 for ansible with change
Ibfd5e745b7c5836b1c421b06ff8ef1e122c14108. Remove the now unused
filter for gate-openstack-ansible.*-bashate.

Change-Id: Iec24aab37d453570b3ee38e7bd763163aa85dae6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/31/257031/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # bashate compliance was only introduced in kilo # this applies to all openstack-ansible repositories - name: ^gate-openstack-ansible.*-bashate$ branch: ^(?!juno).*$

commit_message:
Merge bashate/pep8 lint jobs in common job

Instead of launching two separate build jobs in our CI infrastructure,
one for bashate and one for pep8, launch a single one. While the jobs
are short, the setup of the images takes a long time, so this is
friendlier to our CI infrastructure.

Use the pep8 environment as common lint target and merge the bashate job
into it.

This patch also renamed dev-requirements to test-requirements to bring it
into line with all other OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: I7268b76b48c95e110f141e678d8ad87e0be6b057

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-15 00:34:29.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/plugin.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/ce21995319d2ce9ec50c30ec72374fa8d106a9e2', 'message': 'Make Octavia devstack pass env settings to sudo pip install

Current code to install diskimage-builder requirements in
devstack does not pass on enviroment settings to sudo, which can
cause the pip install to fail behind a proxy.

This happens when the user has http_proxy/https_proxy values set
but not for root.  The stack.sh runs and installs for a while,
before failing on the Octavia diskimage-builder.

commit_message:
Make Octavia devstack pass env settings to sudo pip install

Current code to install diskimage-builder requirements in
devstack does not pass on enviroment settings to sudo, which can
cause the pip install to fail behind a proxy.

This happens when the user has http_proxy/https_proxy values set
but not for root.  The stack.sh runs and installs for a while,
before failing on the Octavia diskimage-builder.

Change-Id: I196aca7004ea0eed713877e54ba10dcfe1d343e7
Closes-Bug: #1526108
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/29/257629/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo -E pip install -r $DEST/diskimage-builder/requirements.txt

commit_message:
Option to supress logs for in_process test

With switch to ostestr all the server logs are being sent to stdout
which makes it completely unreadable. Adding an option to suppress
the logs.

Change-Id: I9916e06068c57973fb443e4c8ef2ed4c98c562e7
Signed-off-by: Ganesh Maharaj Mahalingam <ganesh.mahalingam@intel.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/57/255457/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: test_command=SWIFT_SUPPRESS_LOGS=${SWIFT_SUPPRESS_LOGS:False} \ ${PYTHON:-python} -m subunit.run discover . $LISTOPT $IDOPTION

commit_message:
puppet: unpin bundler for unit & syntax jobs

Bundler 1.11.1 [1] has been released so we don't need to pin our CI,
since this release includes the Psych fix [2].

[1] https://github.com/bundler/bundler/releases/tag/v1.11.1
[2] https://github.com/bundler/bundler/commit/4c8a0f479ee9da79019907de43f7414bf820b250

Change-Id: Ib04bcd68954cff830992a099d90030d7b8207978

Change-Id: I7b3c0cf024b7f5185ddf2198fbb01351c269ba0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/27/254427/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Glance image signature uses an insecure hash algorithm (MD5) --- ### Summary ### During the Liberty release the Glance project added a feature that supports verifying images by their signature. There is a flaw in the implementation that degrades verification by using the weak MD5 algorithm. ### Affected Services / Software ### Glance, Liberty ### Discussion ### A signature algorithm is typically created by hashing data and then encrypting that hash in some way. In the case of the new Glance feature the signature algorithm does not hash the image to be verified. It rehashes the existing MD5 checksum that is used to locally verify the integrity of image data stored in Glance. The Glance image signature algorithm uses SHA256, a suitable algorithm for this purpose but instead of applying it to the image data it's applied only to the MD5 checksum that already exists in Glance. This degrades the overall security of the algorithm. The image signature algorithm is a relatively new feature, introduced in the Liberty release. ### Recommended Actions ### Users concerned with image security should be aware that the current Glance signature algorithm is not secure by todays cryptographic standards. <Waiting for feedback from the Glance team on how/when of a fix> ### Contacts / References ### This OSSN : https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OSSN/OSSN-0061 Original LaunchPad Bug : https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1516031 OpenStack Security ML : openstack-security@lists.openstack.org OpenStack Security Group : https://launchpad.net/~openstack-ossg CVE: CVE-2015-8234

commit_message:
DVR: handle dvr serviceable port's host change

When a VM port's host is changed we need to check if a router
should be unscheduled from old host and send corresponding
notifications.
commit d5a8074ec3c67ed68e64a96827da990f1c34e10f added such
a check when port is unbound. This patch adds similar check
in case of host change (instance live migration)

Closes-Bug: #1508869

Change-Id: I57fa8253b2c88f7b7380a79b841fc424e9e52f19
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/78/238478/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # register l3 agents in dvr mode in addition to existing dvr_snat agent HOST1 = 'host1' dvr_agent1 = helpers.register_l3_agent( host=HOST1, agent_mode=l3_const.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR) HOST2 = 'host2' dvr_agent2 = helpers.register_l3_agent( host=HOST2, agent_mode=l3_const.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR) self.l3_plugin.agent_notifiers[ l3_const.AGENT_TYPE_L3] = l3_notifier {'port': {'binding:host_id': HOST1}}) # now router should be scheduled to dvr_snat agent and # dvr agent on host1 self.assertIn(dvr_agent1['id'], self.assertNotIn(dvr_agent2['id'], [agent['id'] for agent in agents['agents']]) # and notification should only be sent to the agent on host1 self.context, {router['id']}, HOST1) # updating port's host (instance migration) l3_notifier.reset_mock() self.core_plugin.update_port( self.context, port['port']['id'], {'port': {'binding:host_id': HOST2}}) # now router should be scheduled to dvr_snat agent and # dvr agent on host2 agents = self.l3_plugin.list_l3_agents_hosting_router( self.context, router['id']) self.assertEqual(2, len(agents['agents'])) self.assertIn(dvr_agent2['id'], [agent['id'] for agent in agents['agents']]) self.assertNotIn(dvr_agent1['id'], [agent['id'] for agent in agents['agents']]) l3_notifier.routers_updated_on_host.assert_called_once_with( self.context, {router['id']}, HOST2) l3_notifier.router_removed_from_agent.assert_called_once_with( self.context, router['id'], HOST1)
deleted_lines: # register l3 agent in dvr mode in addition to existing dvr_snat agent HOST = 'host1' dvr_agent = helpers.register_l3_agent( host=HOST, agent_mode=l3_const.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR) {'port': {'binding:host_id': HOST}}) # now router should be scheduled to both agents self.assertIn(dvr_agent['id'], # and notification should only be sent to the agent on HOST self.context, {router['id']}, HOST)

commit_message:
Add Port port_security_enabled property

Explicitly parse the port_security_enabled property for a
Port object based on the property's definition in the
networking v2 API [1].

[1] http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-networking-v2.html

Change-Id: Ibd0fdd429abbea44cd56d6901f6709e8c5663f19
Closes-Bug: #1526441

commit_message:
Chronicles of a DLM

Distributed locks, the concept, the problem space, what
has been done, what could be done, what will be done,
what must be done, the journey begins now (weekdays at
7pm EST).

Updating due to summit session result, some more small
work and/or tweaks still needed.

Change-Id: Ibce47659c1108b94b4d538c63da69ce0371aed04
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-specs refs/changes/61/209661/33 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================================== Chronicles of a distributed lock manager ========================================== No blueprint, this is intended as a reference/consensus document. The various OpenStack projects have an ongoing requirements to perform some set of actions in an atomic manner over a distributed set of applications on some set of distributed resources **without** having those resources end up in some corrupted state due to actions being performed on them without the traditional concept of `locking`_. A `DLM`_ is one such concept/solution that can help (but not entirely solve) these types of common resource manipulation patterns in distributed systems. This specification will be an attempt at defining the problem space, understanding what each project *currently* has done in regards of creating its own `DLM`_-like entity and how we can make the situation better by coming to consensus on a common solution that we can benefit from to make everyone's lives (developers, operators and users of OpenStack projects) that much better. .. _DLM: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_lock_manager .. _locking: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lock_%28computer_science%29 Problem description =================== <WIP> Proposed change =============== <WIP> Alternatives ------------ <WIP> Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- - All the reviewers, code creators, PTL(s) of OpenStack? Work Items ---------- <WIP> Dependencies ============ <WIP> History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Update os.path.remove as it does not exist

Os.path.remove does not exist so this removes it and replaces it with
some code that will remove the file. Functionally fulfilling the role
that os.path.remove was meant to fill.

Change-Id: I040d445007055b31561a592dd74b3e2ffaa9cd54
Closes-bug: 1507564
(cherry picked from commit 57c50ec6a6268c50a818d1883d571c618ba7a4e3)

commit_message:
remove ctype from classes

The ctype class variable in api_samples dates back to when we were
doing both xml and json api testing with them. xml is done, we can
remove all the ctype class variables as they are fully vestigial.

Change-Id: I61361d1d9d3c5b6de38b57aaef16debdba326865

commit_message:
Remove cells service from api samples that don't test cells

Instead of having cells service started for every api samples test,
whether or not it is used, only start it on test_cells. This saves
some setup / teardown time, and makes things a bit more explicit.

It also removes the cells service from service listing for a couple of
api samples (az and hosts). That's more indicative of what people will
see in real systems as cells is still a minority and experimental
deploy option.

Change-Id: Ie6d7e8978fd2b3441a141c69d4191266d76e7327

commit_message:
Install puppet using build_git system-config

When running disk image builder use the build specific checkout of
system-config to install puppet and puppet modules. This allows for easy
local testing of changes to those scripts. Without it master is always
used.

Change-Id: Ifc86d77f702633d630adc1ee619f58607cb56c82

commit_message:
Redefine Release Management team mission

With the spin-off of the Stable branch maintenance subteam into
its own independent team, it makes sense to revisit the mission
of the Release Management team.

The old "Release Cycle Management" team used to regroup the
Release team, the Stable branch team and the Vulnerability
Management team. Now it's only the Release team left, so we
should also rename it to the name that everyone is calling us
anyway ("Release Management").

Also update the IRC channel and the wiki landing page.

Change-Id: I71b77d350dea2d2e697e6c59792d38a0274bda28

subject: Spin off stable team as separate team
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-09 09:40:24.000000000', 'files': ['reference/projects.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/87bf5c9b63815843dd9eac87bd5295bab5473b82', 'message': 'Spin off stable team as separate team

The Stable branch maintenance team used to be a subteam of the
Release cycle management team, much like the Vulnerability
Management team. However, its tasks were mostly handled by a
separate group, and not having its own identity and PTL arguably
prevented it from reaching the next level.

As the Release team recenters purely on release mechanisms, it
makes sense to spin off the stable branch maintenance under its
own team under the big tent. An election was run to select an
initial PTL and Matt Riedemann was elected.

The Release team mission statement will be redefined in a
subsequent commit to remove deprecated missions.

Change-Id: I8c64b2ca18af4fdb93b33e99c6b9a60223cd2d32
'}]
commit_message:
Spin off stable team as separate team

The Stable branch maintenance team used to be a subteam of the
Release cycle management team, much like the Vulnerability
Management team. However, its tasks were mostly handled by a
separate group, and not having its own identity and PTL arguably
prevented it from reaching the next level.

As the Release team recenters purely on release mechanisms, it
makes sense to spin off the stable branch maintenance under its
own team under the big tent. An election was run to select an
initial PTL and Matt Riedemann was elected.

The Release team mission statement will be redefined in a
subsequent commit to remove deprecated missions.

Change-Id: I8c64b2ca18af4fdb93b33e99c6b9a60223cd2d32

commit_message:
[Verify] Adding possibility to specify concurrency for tests

The `rally verify start` command doesn't allow us to specify
concurrency for Tempest tests. The tests always are run in parallel
mode and use concurrency equal to the count of CPU cores. However,
users may want to use specific concurrency for running tests based
on their deployments and available resources.

This patch adds possibility to specify desired concurrency for tests.

Closes-Bug: #1524968

Change-Id: I3ba2c987c739b13bb03005b1988ee6bd01e8a08d

commit_message:
Merge bashate/pep8 lint jobs in common job

Instead of launching two separate build jobs in our CI infrastructure,
one for bashate and one for pep8, launch a single one. While the jobs
are short, the setup of the images takes a long time, so this is
friendlier to our CI infrastructure.

Use the pep8 environment as common lint target and merge the bashate job
into it.

This patch also renamed dev-requirements to test-requirements to bring it
into line with all other OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: Ib2683cba4c4dafa7f8391c51be1c8c5319e79488

subject: VNX: Fix issue in deleting cg/cgsnapshot
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-11 07:30:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/09e4da1c12726857027492628ca183a78c371a7c', 'message': "VNX: Fix issue in deleting cg/cgsnapshot

If user deletes a cg/cgsnapshot quickly after its creation,
driver would report 'not found' warning, and return success
for the deletion, but actually, the object underlying the VNX
is not deleted.

This fix tries to wait the cg and cg snapshot to be available
to make sure it's eligible for deletion.

liberty-backport-potential
Closes-Bug: 1499615
(cherry picked from commit f7b5655d188bfde96333760bbe634f45d4a16395)

Change-Id: Ifae57b9e95e01b1789a37ac7c03e9aad65cd50f7
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-12-12 09:30:50.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/unit/test_emc_vnxdirect.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/emc/emc_vnx_cli.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/07e8c6728b5543dcec80ffad0c18972a7a6d2223', 'message': "VNX: Fix issue in deleting cg/cgsnapshot

If user deletes a cg/cgsnapshot quickly after its creation,
driver would report 'not found' warning, and return success
for the deletion, but actually, the object underlying the VNX
is not deleted.

This fix tries to wait the cg and cg snapshot to be available
to make sure it's eligible for deletion.

liberty-backport-potential

commit_message:
VNX: Fix issue in deleting cg/cgsnapshot

If user deletes a cg/cgsnapshot quickly after its creation,
driver would report 'not found' warning, and return success
for the deletion, but actually, the object underlying the VNX
is not deleted.

This fix tries to wait the cg and cg snapshot to be available
to make sure it's eligible for deletion.

liberty-backport-potential
Closes-Bug: 1499615
(cherry picked from commit f7b5655d188bfde96333760bbe634f45d4a16395)

Change-Id: Ifae57b9e95e01b1789a37ac7c03e9aad65cd50f7

commit_message:
Fix dvr_single_node failure with OVERRIDE_ENABLED_SERVICES flag

Recent change in project-infra introduced a bug that would cause
the dvr-single node jobs to fail.
Patch id: I29e3e098bd972b88551db70e280aa86facbd8f42

This patch address the issue by taking into account the flag
OVERRIDE_ENABLED_SERVICES and the neutron_dvr job to perform
the intial setup right.

Change-Id: If10e651acf0f65739d36dddd37f7b45d78f2d81e
Related-Bug: #1521846
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/69/252569/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ ! -z $OVERRIDE_ENABLED_SERVICES ]] && [[ "$DEVSTACK_GATE_NEUTRON_DVR" != "1"]]; then elif [[ ! -z $OVERRIDE_ENABLED_SERVICES ]]; then MY_ENABLED_SERVICES+=,$OVERRIDE_ENABLED_SERVICES

commit_message:
Check if device exists before taking action on device

Check for the device existence before taking action
on the device.
Recent change in ip_lib.IPDevice introduced an exists
function.
Some of the function in L3 agent today handles this
check but some does not check for the device state.

This patch would add the check for all devices before
attempting to take action on the device.

Change-Id: Iff7aad27d13e8f4280bc565866c8a161d89a4e34
Closes-Bug: #1419175

commit_message:
Remove router namespace on compute port migration in dvr

On live migration of compute port from one host to another
host and if no more dvr serviceable ports exist in the
host, the router namespace is not removed.

The router namespace should be removed if no more dvr
serviceable port in the original host.

This patch addresses the above issue by deleting the router
namespace when a compute port migrates from original host
to new host.

Closes-Bug: #1518444
Change-Id: Ic0dd04e6c5ebde3031569990ada852b270b29443

commit_message:
Remove unused add_sample()

add_sample() has been added since I08c9b6a02bcddd8cab2d066928513b4ae40431ec ,
but we never use this metod over 2 years.
So this patch removes the method for cleanup.

Change-Id: I340d96c27f0e906df5b8a109494920e9cd3b21d1

commit_message:
Merge bashate/pep8 lint jobs in common job

Instead of launching two separate build jobs in our CI infrastructure,
one for bashate and one for pep8, launch a single one. While the jobs
are short, the setup of the images takes a long time, so this is
friendlier to our CI infrastructure.

Use the pep8 environment as common lint target and merge the bashate job
into it.

Change-Id: I96d0e3fe15b792d5bffcc487f712cc9e16c65856

commit_message:
Merge bashate/pep8 lint jobs in common job

Instead of launching two separate build jobs in our CI infrastructure,
one for bashate and one for pep8, launch a single one. While the jobs
are short, the setup of the images takes a long time, so this is
friendlier to our CI infrastructure.

Use the pep8 environment as common lint target and merge the bashate job
into it.

This patch also renamed dev-requirements to test-requirements to bring it
into line with all other OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: Id282271e49cf427ada6a1bb5676c49463eb4420b

commit_message:
Configure workers for Ceilometer services

Workers option can be set for Ceilometer API, Collector
and Agent Notification services. This patch uses upstream
commit: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/226011/

Change-Id: I8d12d32959f6970bf555b5182ff49c55249132bc
Closes-bug: #1522475

commit_message:
Fill cinder scheduler filters from cinder modular manifest

Current scheme of filling cinder conf  with updated scheduler filters
in openstack-controller modular manifest is not good, because it is out
of cinder modular task and that's why cinder services could not be
restarted. Let's move this filling to cinder modular manifest.

Change-Id: I7c3bd0c553762b830e3dc48cdc7138664dd5886f
Closes-bug: #1522876

'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-12-14 13:47:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/aodh/commit/10ff9a5b5c81c3f9605fe9f87e3a53236a187a4b', 'message': 'Fixup our rbac system

The only rule that work in our current rbac system
is context_is_admin, because we never pass
the "target" (the alarm/alarm_change) to oslo.policy
enforcer.

Also whatever the policy file looks like only the segregation
rule worked.

This change fixes that by providing a "target" to oslo.policy.

Now, by default project owner of the alarm should be able
to change their alarms. And anyone can create a new alarm.

About alarms query/listing, now we first checks the action
according the corresponding policy rule, and then
applies the segration rules to filter our alarms if needed.
(Before the policy checks was always succeed, only the segration was
working)

This change fixes the rbac system.

This also fix the heat gate.

Closes-bug: #1504495
Change-Id: I408d839eec84af46adb333a6ad5c49c890513fd0
'}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2015-12-14 14:41:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/aodh/commit/38168447beb7e4305440bd2efcf74784e88c3ac5', 'message': "Fixup our rbac system

Our rbac system, doesn't allow to filter alarms
by project or user, everything is scoped to the
projcet-id (exception for role that match the
segregation rule). So removed useless rules from
our policy.

This change fixes that.

This also fix the heat gate.

Related-bug: #1504495
Change-Id: I408d839eec84af46adb333a6ad5c49c890513fd0

commit_message:
Fix rbac system

After investigation of the heat breakage, after
we update the policy.json. We discover
that the rbac have never worked as expected.
The only rule that works is role == admin. All other
just can't works.

So the policy file have been changed to, By default project
owner of the alarm should be able to change their alarms.
And anyone can create a new alarm.

Also the alarm definition is now passed to the policy enforcer
to allow it checks owner of the alarms.

Closes-bug: #1504495
Change-Id: I408d839eec84af46adb333a6ad5c49c890513fd0

commit_message:
show queue status on integration test

it's useful to check queue status to see how backed up the queues
are to pinpoint performance issues.

Change-Id: I85974c1a2a1f8967244867e8241f462689fd1fc1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/62/255962/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo "* Message queue status:" sudo rabbitmqctl list_queues | grep -e \\.sample -e \\.info

commit_message:
Implements proper UUID format for the test_compute_api

Currently some of the unittests are using non valid UUID format
for the FieldType UUID.

This is preparation work to add UUID validation in the
oslo_versionedobjects/fields.py.

Without this change adding validation will cause tests to fail.

Depends-On: Ie15c0becad4f016ae730c7fa47d6ec21fdec8783
Change-Id: Id5b67dc2ca54d7accd24220959e4e09de0ccccb3

commit_message:
syslog restart infinite loop fix

Hopefully fixes the problems caused by syslog restarting.
The problem is discussed here: http://bugs.python.org/issue15179

I restarted rsyslog a bunch of times with this patch while running functional
tests and didn't see the infinite loop problems anymore.

Change-Id: Id24c358763c190073d433659b62cd0b8d0f91ba9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/71/24871/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: orig_sysloghandler = utils.ReconnectingSysLogHandler utils.ReconnectingSysLogHandler = syslog_handler_catcher utils.ReconnectingSysLogHandler = orig_sysloghandler def test_reconnecting_logger(self): class fakesocket(object): def __init__(self, *args): self.closed = True def connect(self, *args): self.closed = False if error_on_connect: raise socket.error('whatever') def close(self): self.closed = True def send(self, *args): raise socket.error('whatever') with patch('socket.socket', fakesocket): # make sure the real syslog handler leaves socket open on error error_on_connect = False handler = utils.SysLogHandler(address='/dev/log') error_on_connect = True handler.emit(logging.LogRecord('hi', 1, 'whatever', 3, 'some', [], None)) self.assertFalse(handler.socket.closed) with patch('eventlet.green.socket.socket', fakesocket): # make sure the reconnecting syslog handler properly closes it error_on_connect = False handler = utils.ReconnectingSysLogHandler(address='/dev/log') error_on_connect = True handler.emit(logging.LogRecord('hi', 1, 'whatever', 3, 'some', [], None)) self.assert_(handler.socket.closed)
deleted_lines: orig_sysloghandler = utils.SysLogHandler utils.SysLogHandler = syslog_handler_catcher utils.SysLogHandler = orig_sysloghandler

commit_message:
Add networking diagnostic output to validation

Add some basic networking diagnostic informaiton to the network
validation steps. These commands don't actually validate anything, they
just provide useful information to help tell what may have gone wrong in
case the validation steps fail.

commit_message:
Add --skip-validation-checks cli arg

Adds a new cli arg, defaulting to False, to skip validation checks
entirely.  This can be useful for testing and development scenarios.

Change-Id: If480b437c149038fe6cac2ed7b76e9818562b541

commit_message:
Validation cli args improvements

This commit reorganizes the validation cli args into:

--validation-errors-fatal
--validation-errors-nonfatal
--validation-warnings-fatal
--validation-warnings-nonfatal

Errors are fatal by default. This is change from the previous behavior.
However, the change is not all that impactful since many of the fatal
validations aren't actually handled by the existing
--validation-errors-fatal.

Warnings are not fatal by default.

The new cli args give better explicit control over how the validations
are handled. This is done in preparation for the subsequent commits in
this patch series to make sure that all validations that are run by
tripleoclient are properly handled by these cli args.

Change-Id: Ice4424abebcc186aaebfa98013b7c56fe7e82f28
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/05/232105/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: default=True,

subject: Make sure bdm.volume_id is set after auto-creating volumes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-07 22:49:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/20cee3b49070d4b373a44cb5beeaa3dcd7409c4d', 'message': "WIP: Make sure bdm.volume_id is set after auto-creating volumes

The test_create_ebs_image_and_check_boot test in Tempest does the
following:

1. create volume1 from an image
2. boot server1 from volume1 (wait for the server to be ACTIVE)
3. create snapshot from server1 (creates image and volume snapshots)
4. delete server1
5. create server2 from the image snapshot (don't wait for it to be
   ACTIVE) - this auto-creates a volume from the volume snapshot in
   cinder and attaches server2 to it)
6. delete server2 (could still be building/attaching volumes in the
   background)
7. cleanup

There is a race when booting server2 such that the
block_device_mapping.volume_id field may not be set by the time we've
created volume2 and attached it to server2 and the delete request is
made for server2.

So the delete request starts tearing down and looking for volume BDMs so
the compute manager can terimnate the connection, detach the volume and,
if bdm.delete_on_termination is True, delete the volume (which it is in
this case).

We have to save off the volume_id on the BDM after we've auto-created
the volume from the snapshot_id (or image_id or when creating a blank
volume for that matter). This is so the _shutdown_instance and
_cleanup_volumes code in the compute manager can properly attempt the
detach and volume delete.

In the case of race bug, deleting the volume snapshot in cinder fails
because volume2 was never deleted by nova, so the test fails in
teardown.

Closes-Bug: #1464259

Change-Id: Ib60d60a5af35be89ad8afbcf44fcffe0b0ce2876
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-12-08 20:41:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0d7f1c8f32d56b94d323c95d06830eeb9a821ada', 'message': "Make sure bdm.volume_id is set after auto-creating volumes

The test_create_ebs_image_and_check_boot test in Tempest does the
following:

1. create volume1 from an image
2. boot server1 from volume1 with delete_on_termination=True and wait
   for the server to be ACTIVE
3. create snapshot from server1 (creates image and volume snapshots)
4. delete server1
5. create server2 from the image snapshot (don't wait for it to be
   ACTIVE - this auto-creates volume2 from the volume snapshot in
   cinder and attaches server2 to it)
6. delete server2 (could still be building/attaching volumes in the
   background)
7. cleanup

There is a race when booting server2 such that the
block_device_mapping.volume_id field may not be set by the time we've
created volume2 and attached it to server2 and the delete request is
made for server2.

So the delete request starts tearing down and looking for volume BDMs so
the compute manager can terimnate the connection, detach the volume and,
if bdm.delete_on_termination is True, delete the volume (which it is in
this case).

We have to save off the volume_id on the BDM after we've auto-created
the volume from the snapshot_id (or image_id or when creating a blank
volume for that matter). This is so the _shutdown_instance and
_cleanup_volumes code in the compute manager can properly attempt the
detach and volume delete.

In the case of race bug, deleting the volume snapshot in cinder fails
because volume2 was never deleted by nova, so the test fails in
teardown.

This also cleans up the logging in attach_block_devices since there
may not be a volume_id at that point (depending on bdm.source_type),
and also fixes the compute manager _shutdown_instance bdm filtering
code. BlockDeviceMapping.is_volume only checks the destination_type
is 'volume', but the _shutdown_instance code needs the bdm.volume_id
to be set.

Closes-Bug: #1464259

Change-Id: Ib60d60a5af35be89ad8afbcf44fcffe0b0ce2876
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-12-09 21:57:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2f7bda258bd9c7fa38f991eb57be837787623f38', 'message': "Make sure bdm.volume_id is set after auto-creating volumes

The test_create_ebs_image_and_check_boot test in Tempest does the
following:

1. create volume1 from an image
2. boot server1 from volume1 with delete_on_termination=True and wait
   for the server to be ACTIVE
3. create snapshot from server1 (creates image and volume snapshots)
4. delete server1
5. create server2 from the image snapshot (don't wait for it to be
   ACTIVE - this auto-creates volume2 from the volume snapshot in
   cinder and attaches server2 to it)
6. delete server2 (could still be building/attaching volumes in the
   background)
7. cleanup

There is a race when booting server2 such that the
block_device_mapping.volume_id field may not be set by the time we've
created volume2 and attached it to server2 and the delete request is
made for server2.

So the delete request starts tearing down and looking for volume BDMs so
the compute manager can terminate the connection, detach the volume and,
if bdm.delete_on_termination is True, delete the volume (which it is in
this case).

We have to save off the volume_id on the BDM after we've auto-created
the volume from the snapshot_id (or image_id or when creating a blank
volume for that matter). This is so the _shutdown_instance and
_cleanup_volumes code in the compute manager can properly attempt the
detach and volume delete.

In the case of the race bug, deleting the volume snapshot in cinder fails
because volume2 was never deleted by nova, so the test fails in
teardown. Note that there is still potential for a race here, this does
not eliminate it, but should narrow the race window. That's why we log
a warning in _shutdown_instance if the bdm.volume_id is not set.

This also cleans up the logging in attach_block_devices since there
may not be a volume_id at that point (depending on bdm.source_type),
and also fixes the compute manager _shutdown_instance bdm filtering
code. BlockDeviceMapping.is_volume only checks the destination_type
is 'volume', but the _shutdown_instance code needs the bdm.volume_id
to be set.

Closes-Bug: #1464259

Change-Id: Ib60d60a5af35be89ad8afbcf44fcffe0b0ce2876

The test_create_ebs_image_and_check_boot test in Tempest does the
following:

1. create volume1 from an image
2. boot server1 from volume1 with delete_on_termination=True and wait
   for the server to be ACTIVE
3. create snapshot from server1 (creates image and volume snapshots)
4. delete server1
5. create server2 from the image snapshot (don't wait for it to be
   ACTIVE - this auto-creates volume2 from the volume snapshot in
   cinder and attaches server2 to it)
6. delete server2 (could still be building/attaching volumes in the
   background)
7. cleanup

There is a race when booting server2 such that the
block_device_mapping.volume_id field may not be set by the time we've
created volume2 and attached it to server2 and the delete request is
made for server2.

So the delete request starts tearing down and looking for volume BDMs so
the compute manager can terminate the connection, detach the volume and,
if bdm.delete_on_termination is True, delete the volume (which it is in
this case).

We have to save off the volume_id on the BDM after we've auto-created
the volume from the snapshot_id (or image_id or when creating a blank
volume for that matter). This is so the _shutdown_instance and
_cleanup_volumes code in the compute manager can properly attempt the
detach and volume delete.

There is also the case that the block_device attach does complete before
we get to _shutdown_instance and the database is updated, but after the
delete request is in the API - where compute API gets potentially stale
BDMs and passes those over RPC to the compute. So we add a check in
_shutdown_instance to see if we have potentially stale volume BDMs and
refresh that list if so. This is not a cure-all, but it should also help
to narrow the race window.

In the case of the race bug, deleting the volume snapshot in cinder fails
because volume2 was never deleted by nova, so the test fails in
teardown. Note that there is still potential for a race here, this does
not eliminate it, but should narrow the race window. That's why we log
a warning in _shutdown_instance if the bdm.volume_id is not set.

This also cleans up the logging in attach_block_devices since there
may not be a volume_id at that point (depending on bdm.source_type),
and also fixes the compute manager _shutdown_instance bdm filtering
code. BlockDeviceMapping.is_volume only checks the destination_type
is 'volume', but the _shutdown_instance code needs the bdm.volume_id
to be set.

Closes-Bug: #1464259

Change-Id: Ib60d60a5af35be89ad8afbcf44fcffe0b0ce2876

The test_create_ebs_image_and_check_boot test in Tempest does the
following:

1. create volume1 from an image
2. boot server1 from volume1 with delete_on_termination=True and wait
   for the server to be ACTIVE
3. create snapshot from server1 (creates image and volume snapshots)
4. delete server1
5. create server2 from the image snapshot (don't wait for it to be
   ACTIVE - this auto-creates volume2 from the volume snapshot in
   cinder and attaches server2 to it)
6. delete server2 (could still be building/attaching volumes in the

volume2, and deleting server2 before it's active.

The volume attach completes and updates the bdm.volume_id in the DB before
we get to _shutdown_instance, but after the delete request is in the API.
The compute API gets potentially stale BDMs and passes those over RPC to
the compute. So we add a check in _shutdown_instance to see if we have
potentially stale volume BDMs and refresh that list if so.

The instance.uuid locks in build_and_run_instance and terminate_instance
create the mutex on the compute host such that the bdm.volume_id should
be set in the database after the volume attach and before terminate_instance
gets the lock. The bdm.volume_id could still be None in _shutdown_instance
if the volume create fails, but we don't have anything to teardown in cinder
in that case anyway.

In the case of the race bug, deleting the volume snapshot in cinder fails
because volume2 was never deleted by nova, so the test fails in
teardown. Note that there is still potential for a race here, this does
not eliminate it, but should narrow the race window.

This also cleans up the logging in attach_block_devices since there
may not be a volume_id at that point (depending on bdm.source_type).

Closes-Bug: #1464259

Change-Id: Ib60d60a5af35be89ad8afbcf44fcffe0b0ce2876
